+namespace algorithms::graph::articulation_points
+{
+    /**
+     * Let's say there is a node ğ‘‰ in some graph ğº
+ that can be reached by a node ğ‘ˆ
+ through some intermediate nodes (maybe non intermediate nodes) following some DFS traversal, if ğ‘‰
+ can also be reached by ğ´
+ = "ancestor of ğ‘ˆ
+" without passing through ğ‘ˆ
+ then, ğ‘ˆ
+ is NOT an articulation point because it means that if we remove ğ‘ˆ
+ from ğº
+ we can still reach ğ‘‰
+ from ğ´
+, hence, the number of connected components will remain the same.
+
+So, we can conclude that the only 2 conditions for ğ‘ˆ
+ to be an articulation point are:
+
+If all paths from ğ´
+ to ğ‘‰
+ require ğ‘ˆ
+ to be in the graph.
+
+If ğ‘ˆ
+ is the root of the DFS traversal with at least 2 children subgraphs disconnected from each other.
+     * 
+     */
+}
\ No newline at end of file

@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+
+
+namespace algorithms::graph::articulation_point
+{
+
+using 
+
+    /**
+     * https://codeforces.com/blog/entry/71146
+     * Let's say there is a node ğ‘‰ in some graph ğº that can be reached by a node ğ‘ˆ
+     * through some intermediate nodes (maybe non intermediate nodes) following some DFS traversal, 
+     * if ğ‘‰ can also be reached by ğ´ = "ancestor of ğ‘ˆ " without passing through ğ‘ˆ then, ğ‘ˆ
+     * is NOT an articulation point because it means that if we remove ğ‘ˆ from ğº
+     * we can still reach ğ‘‰ from A, hence, the number of connected components will remain the same.
+     * So, we can conclude that the only 2 conditions for ğ‘ˆ to be an articulation point are:
+     * 1 - If all paths from ğ´ to ğ‘‰ require ğ‘ˆ to be in the graph.
+     * 2 - If ğ‘ˆ is the root of the DFS traversal with at least 2 children subgraphs disconnected from each other.
+     */
+
+    ap = low = disc = vector<int>(adj.size());
+}
